importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: This is the date the news article was published, marking the latest update on the ongoing flooding crisis in Mexico.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The flooding event occurred during the previous week, with the most intense rainfall reported on Wednesday, indicating a recent and urgent environmental emergency.

keyTakeAways: At least 64 people have died in Mexico due to heavy rains and flooding in five states.
Another 65 people are still missing, with the majority reported in Hidalgo, Veracruz, and Puebla.
The states most affected are Veracruz (29 deaths), Hidalgo (21 deaths), Puebla (13 deaths), and Queretaro (1 death).
Approximately 100,000 houses have been affected, with some homes near rivers reportedly 'practically disappeared'.
The flooding was caused by remnants of Hurricane Priscilla and Tropical Rainstorm Raymond, leading to rapid river rises and landslides.
The heaviest rainfall occurred in Cerro Azul (Veracruz) and Cuetzalan del Progreso (Puebla), with 280mm and 286mm of rain respectively.
Thousands of military personnel, including the Army, Air Force, and National Guard, have been deployed to deliver food, water, and aid.
Nearly 400 repair workers have restored over 80% of the electricity supply to affected areas where about 263,000 users lost power.
Governors are coordinating efforts, and the National Civil Protection Coordination (CNPC) chief Laura Velazquez Alzua reported on the situation during President Claudia Sheinbaum’s daily briefing.
Sheinbaum stated that there were no prior meteorological warnings indicating the magnitude of rainfall, raising concerns about early warning systems.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Heavy rains from the remnants of Hurricane Priscilla and Tropical Rainstorm Raymond caused catastrophic flooding and landslides across five Mexican states, leading to at least 64 deaths and 65 people still missing. The worst-hit areas include Veracruz (29 deaths), Hidalgo (21 deaths), and Puebla (13 deaths), with extreme rainfall recorded in Cerro Azul and Cuetzalan del Progreso. The National Civil Protection Coordination, led by Laura Velazquez Alzua, coordinated emergency responses involving thousands of military personnel, including the Army, Air Force, and National Guard, who delivered food, water, and medical aid. Electricity services were severely disrupted, affecting around 263,000 users, but nearly 80% of power has been restored. President Claudia Sheinbaum highlighted the absence of prior meteorological warnings, raising concerns about Mexico’s early warning systems and preparedness for extreme weather events.
title: Mexico flooding death toll rises to 64, with dozens still missing
